body: The old version from v0.1.0 to v0.7.0 were released before IoTDB entered Apache Incubator, so after rethinking, I think it is good that if we begin the version of Apache IoTDB from 0.8.0.
Can anyone review and approve this pr?
you shouldn't exclude "*.md" files ... they are not binary and it's easy to add comments the normal xml style with (<!-- and -->)

> you shouldn't exclude "*.md" files ... they are not binary and it's easy to add comments the normal xml style with ()

Hm... but it is strange if we add ASF header on a Readme.md file for readers...

I checked some other projects, their readme file or some other *.md files do not have the asf header.

e.g.,
https://github.com/apache/incubator-plc4x/blob/develop/README
https://github.com/apache/incubator-plc4x/blob/develop/DEVELOPMENT.md
https://github.com/apache/cassandra/blob/trunk/TESTING.md
https://github.com/apache/cassandra/blob/trunk/README.asc

Well the README, RELEASE_NOTES, NOTICE and DISCLAIMER don't have those for us, but all the other files do. It's still a product of your project documentation isn't much different than code and should have headers in them (my personal oppinion).

I wasn't opposed by excluding the root README file, I was just opposed by generally excluding markdown files.

> Well the README, RELEASE_NOTES, NOTICE and DISCLAIMER don't have those for us, but all the other files do. It's still a product of your project documentation isn't much different than code and should have headers in them (my personal oppinion).
> 
> I wasn't opposed by excluding the root README file, I was just opposed by generally excluding markdown files.

* All MardDown files (except for .github/**/*.md which are generated by Github for describing issues and others' templates)  are added the ASF header.
* I comment the license-maven-plugin, and add a comment to say that we do not recommend to use it for avoiding out-of-control.

For integration tests, should we put them into src/test/it folder?
I think it's better to open an issue(include description, implementation, documents, etc) in jira. All pull requests should be associated in this issue.

> For integration tests, should we put them into src/test/it folder?

The default ITs the plugin defines is:
<includes>
    <include>**/IT*.java</include>
    <include>**/*IT.java</include>
    <include>**/*ITCase.java</include>
</includes>

What I want to modify is that adding some actions in pre-integration and post-integration phase (e.g., start IoTDB and stop it). But, we can do it in the future.

I consider that m2 and sonar caches are used for speeding up Maven test.

So, can we also speed up the download of JDK?

Normally, it takes about 5 minutes to execute `mvn clean integration-test` command. If it takes more than 5 minutes, downloading jdk becomes a bottleneck of our travis test speed.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8021527/53151883-22465000-35ef-11e9-923b-bf648856fa47.png)

I will merge this PR. 
Cache downloading JDK can be submitted in a new PR.
Please check travis results frequently and ensure that failure of tests is not caused by OpenFileNumTest. Try to retrigger those failed tests as soon as possible.
please solve the conflict files before we start review...

> 2nd phase review...

fixed.

Is it necessary to add this parameter? 

If we ask user to set use.local.thrift.compiler = true and configure thrift path manually, this will lead to many unforeseen mistakes because of unknown operations from user. In my opinion, 40MB size is not very large and only need to downloaded once. Also, we will provide a docker image with all dependencies installed in the future.

> Is it necessary to add this parameter?
> 
> If we ask user to set use.local.thrift.compiler = true and configure thrift path manually, this will lead to many unforeseen mistakes because of unknown operations from user. In my opinion, 40MB size is not very large and only need to downloaded once. Also, we will provide a docker image with all dependencies installed in the future.

Downloading it will takes more than 20 minutes....

Normally, users do not need to use this parameter. But if they want to do like this, we give them an option.
As the comments say: if true, you must set the thrift compiler into your PATH, and make sure the version is ${thrift.version}
Are you sure it takes 20 minutes to download thrift-compiler rather than other maven dependencies? If network is poor, it also requires lots of time to download maven dependencies

> Are you sure it takes 20 minutes to download thrift-compiler rather than other maven dependencies? If network is poor, it also requires lots of time to download maven dependencies

At least in China the speed is poor, you can have a try by  checkout the branch `enable_docker_image`, and run `docker build -t test:v1 .`

But in other countries, it is fine. On travis, the Ubuntu image only takes several minutes.

In this PR, I replace many parameters' declaration `TimeValueSortor` with `ReadOnlyMemChunk`, because the owners of these parameters never receive a `TimeValueSortor` instance which is not `ReadOnlyMemChunk`.

At this time, using a parent interface is not quite good, because you will lose many features that  a child class has.

Hi @jixuan1989 a more general comment to you comment above:
Initially I also had it throw an exception if the file is corrupt and no auto repair. But this is not possible currently due to a non-optimal desing.
Basically

Reader -> uses NativeResorableWriter -> uses Reader ....

This circle leads to the problem. as a corrupted file and a reader call WITH auto repair would lead to a call to NativeRestorableIoWriter which calls again the reader WITHOUT restore, which would (as file is corrupted) throw an exception.
We should consider some refactoring, to align the layers in a way, that we can use the same low-leve functions from readers and writers and implement this "repari" logic above, that they do not clash in the way described.
@JulianFeinauer  seems you are right. let me have a think..

> Hi @jixuan1989 a more general comment to you comment above:
> Initially I also had it throw an exception if the file is corrupt and no auto repair. But this is not possible currently due to a non-optimal desing.
> Basically
> 
> Reader -> uses NativeResorableWriter -> uses Reader ....
> 
> This circle leads to the problem. as a corrupted file and a reader call WITH auto repair would lead to a call to NativeRestorableIoWriter which calls again the reader WITHOUT restore, which would (as file is corrupted) throw an exception.
> We should consider some refactoring, to align the layers in a way, that we can use the same low-leve functions from readers and writers and implement this "repari" logic above, that they do not clash in the way described.

@JulianFeinauer 
I have two proposals:
1. I think we can extract the code for repairing a file from `NativeRestorableIOWriter`'s construction function, as `repair(TsFileSequenceReader reader, TsFileOutput output)`, then, a restorable reader `A` can call the function  like `repair(A, new DefaultTsFileOutput(file))`, a restorable writer `B` can call the function like `repair(new TsFileSequenceReader(file, false, false), B)`;

2. Or, do not add the ability of repairing a file to `TsFileSequenceReader`. Instead, add  child class of `TsFileSequenceReader`, e.g., `class RestorableTsFileReader extends TsFileSequenceReader`. Then, the dependiency looks like:

A: `TsFileSequenceReader`
B: `NativeRestorableIOWriter`
C: `RestorableTsFileReader`

then, 
C calls B, B calls A, 
C extends A.
A reads file on disk
B writes data to file on disk.
if the method is only used for test, then I can approve it. Otherwise I think it is important to show that a lock requirement is failed...
So why does it throw an exception when I just input a storage group command?
I will merge this PR and continue to refactor.
